block.p: Markets

Long-term interest rates dropped to record lows again as traders appeared to accept the probability of modest economic growth with low inflation. The 30-year Treasury bond continued its two-week rally, dropping in yield to 6.78 percent. [ Page D1. ]
Stocks rose as equities became more attractive to investors than bonds, which have fallen to record-low yields. The Dow gained 3.51 points, to 3,404.04, and other indexes gained. [ D8. ]
Markets

Long-term interest rates dropped to record lows again as traders appeared to accept the probability of modest economic growth with low inflation. The 30-year Treasury bond continued its two-week rally, dropping in yield to 6.78 percent. [ Page D1. ]
Stocks rose as equities became more attractive to investors than bonds, which have fallen to record-low yields. The Dow gained 3.51 points, to 3,404.04, and other indexes gained. [ D8. ]
The dollar was mixed ahead of a meeting of German monetary officials. Gold was mixed. [ D13. ] Grain prices weakened. [ D13. ] The Economy
Some businesses are delaying plans to rent space in the World Trade Center and some tenants may not renew leases. [ A1. ] The Port Authority successfully sold $100 million in new bonds. [ B5. ]
The Supreme Court, in a case involving Ernst & Young, made it harder to sue accountants, lawyers and other outside advisers to corrupt companies under RICO laws. [ D1. ]
Democrats defeated the first Republican challenge to President Clinton's economic program, voting down a proposal to offset extended unemployment benefits with spending cuts. [ A22. ]
Clark M. Clifford won an indefinite postponement of his trial in the B.C.C.I. scandal. He is planning heart surgery. [ D14. ]
The New York City pension fund sued the S.E.C. for allowing companies to bar shareholder votes on hiring policies. [ D8. ] Companies
Talk radio will come to desktop computers in a few weeks under a plan by a Virginia entrepreneur to broadcast a daily 30-minute radio talk show on Internet, a computer network. [ A1. ]
Television stations are being told by regulators that cartoons like "The Jetsons" and "The Flintstones" can no longer count as "educational and informational" programming. [ A1. ]
Sales of North American-built vehicles rose 9 percent in late February. But the annual car-selling rate slipped. [ D4. ]
The U.A.W. said thousands more G.M. workers than expected had taken an offer of early retirement. [ D4. ]
Mazda dropped discussions with Ford on joint European automobile production because the two could not agree. [ D4. ]
Prudential's capital rose $79 million in 1992 despite a $900 million loss on insurance because of Hurricane Andrew. [ D4. ]
Bristol-Myers Squibb named a president for its pharmaceutical group, which produces more than half its revenues. [ D4. ]
The New York Post was added to the S.E.C. fraud suit against Steven Hoffenberg, who is trying to buy the paper. [ B3. ] International
Airbus unveiled what it called a new airplane developed without government subsidies. But the A321 is not new by most measures, and it can be argued that it was subsidized. [ D1. ]
Mexico's state oil company wants to become a modern oil giant with foreign help. But Pemex's self-imposed ceiling on production has limited its role as a major source of export revenue. [ D1. ]

Administration officials say they are dissatisfied with Japan's efforts to open its market to American computer chips, but they are leaning against imposing any immediate sanctions. [ D1. ] Today's Columns
President Clinton's proposed B.T.U. tax will raise revenue, but the plan is generating a lot of grousing among environmentalists and economists. Peter Passell: Economic Scene. [ D2. ]
What seemed to be more grim news for Gtech Holdings, a maker of computerized lottery systems, has turned out to be good for its stock. Kurt Eichenwald: Market Place. [ D8. ]
Anheuser-Busch has scheduled a new advertising campaign for Bud Dry as part of a multimillion-dollar strategy to "stimulate new interest" in the beer. Advertising. [ D20. ]
